CORRESPONDENCE.

(Editor BOWEN INDEPENDENT)

[We do not hold ourselves responsible for opinions expressed by Correspondents.]

I am, Yours,, etc., JAM BANG SMITH.

Dear Sir, I noticed in your re port of the Hospital Committee’s meeting, published in last Satur day’s issue, a considerable discussion

took place on the attitude taken up by the local Waterside Union in re gard to the matter of hospital con tributions, To elucidate' the public on the matter of the threatening letter said to have been for warded to the Committee I may state that it was in the essence simply a request to their Ultra patriotic secretary to ' practice that which he preached. TheWktersiders are ready and will ing; at any.time to make a fair busi ness deal with the Committee in re gard to contributions. , As for the President’s inane remark about the contribution of one man surely he knows that in a case of this kind, it Is- not the individual but the ag gregate contribution that - counts.' For; him , to state that if the Water sidets want to come in they can make a request atfd the Committee: will consider it, in other words come cap in' hand and ask to be taken in, simply displays an appalling ignor-' anceof the psychology of the lumper. I have, gathered-from a member of the committee that committee-man R«v. Gillespie made use of the ex pression that the attitude taken up by the Watersiders during the re cent conscription campaign placed them outside the pale of civilization. Well; whether civilized or not, the lutqpers havb in their composition enough Christian charity to allow anyoneholding an opposite view to be, sincere and honest in his opinion. As for their attitude on the Referen dum it was endorsed in no uncertain mannerby the boys at the front. :In Conclusion, Mr Editor, I trust that the Hospital Committee will cast ■ aside their high and mighty “meih self und Gott,” notions and realize that, Bowen is awakening from its long somnambulance and that, ap proached' properly, the Watersiders would in the' near future be the source of a substantial income to the Hospital.

BOWEN RIFLE CLUB.

After a weary week of Committee meetings and other “Dry as Dust” functions, the “Independent” repre sentative was loth to give up his

customary afternoon snooze," and foot it out to the rifle range under I the burning sip. The salt pan is not the pleasantest place with the temperature at 91 in the shade, as it was on Sunday. t ./■■■".■ But duty must be'.done so,out he went, and was at first inclined to think he had struck ’a garden ,• with the captain and Club members buz zing, about like . bees among the flowers. Hot and bad tempered he steered for a tent at the 300 yards range, and immediately struck; . twenty, or thirty ladies resting in the shade. Our representative, be ing' essentially a ladies’ . man,, was quickly at ease, and after a long," deliciously cool, need drink, he was able. to. enjoy the really excellent shooting done by the ladies. “An Admirer” had to get his hand down rather unexpectedly,'as Mrs Trower shooting with coolness and determ ination, scored seven bulls in suc cession, being the highest 'possible, and thus won both the first prize, the special cash prize, and one or two others not given by the Club. Miss Bertha Eyles with 30 tied with Mrs Gorey for second place, and putting up a slightly better shot, received second prize. Other good scores were Mrs Schultz 28 (with a miss,) Miss Warburton 27, and Miss Andrews 25. Rifle shooting being a useful accomplishment, as well ,as a healthy sport, we commend to the serious consideration - of the ladies, whether, they might not form ‘ a ladies club, and the Secretary states that the question is-to be discussed at the Committee meeting this week. They are also endeavouring to ar range a match with the Townsville ladies. The Committee desire to thank all the ladies for the keen in terest shown in yesterday’s shooting hope they were satisfied as to of tbq concJiUohs,

BOWEN RIFLE CLUB.

The committee are unanimously in favour of extending the privil eges of honorary membership of the Club to Indies, including the

right to compete in all competitions. This step, boweyer, necessitates the calling of a general meeting of Club members, as the bye-laws will have to be amended for the purpose. It was decided by the committee to leave this oyer until the end.of the year, in order to avoid any addit ional financial outlay for the ladies, as, if they were admitted at once, the half years subscription would immediately fall due. Meanwhile they are invited out to the range for practice as hitherto, and it is probable that the match with the Townsville ladies will be arranged for an early data in December, probably to take place on a Wed nesday afternoon. The Secretary promises full particulars as soon as possible. We heartily endorse the decision of the .committee, and hope the ladies section will become a permanent one. Next Sunday there will be a spell from shooting; but the secretary will be pleased to afford opportunity to any members or ladies wishing to practice if they will him of their intention. Sunday Dec 9tb, a team match with the Winton Rifle Club will be shot, teams will, be published in Tuesday’s Independent and also posted up at Green’s.

CORRESPONDENCE.

To the Editor.

[We do not hold ourselves responsible for opinions expressed by correspondents.]

J. Eyre Massy, Secretary.

J. Eyre-Massey, Secretary, B.P, & N. P. Assn. This was done against the Secre tary’s (Mr.'Massy’S) wish. G. E. KENT," Chairman.

Sir, —In the “Bowen Independ ent” of Saturday, 8th instant, there appeared two notices of meetings of the Bowen Producers and National

Political, Association. One inserted by me, the Chairman, also another inserted by the Secretary in the war budget, copy herewith— BOWEN PRODUCERS and NA TIONAE POEITICAE ASSO CIATION, The regular monthly meeting of the above Association will be held in the Shire Hall Board Room at 9 o’clock this (Saturday) evening, notwithstanding Mr. G. E. Kent’s advertisement in to-day’s issue/ of the “ Bowen Independent ” to the contrary. V

' It is necessary to 'give members and the public a report of the cir cumstances connected with these -notices. On Monday, 3rd inst., about 7 o’clock, before leaving for my farm, I asked my wife to telephone to Mr 'Massy (Secretary) about 10 o’clock and advise him that I would be at the office to sign any cheques and arrange any necessary business at 4 o’clock that day. The Secretary received this message from my wife. At 4 o’ciock I arrived at the office and was informed by his assistant that the Secretary (Mr. Massy) was not in. I waited in the vicinity for ‘ fit least .20 minutes and then left to do my own business. On Tuesday I received an important letter from Prose/pine and the local paper (Tuesday’s)- with a notice of a meeting, inserted by the Secretary. It has been thd usual practice for the Secretary to consult the Chair man before inserting such a notice. I had to go to Proserpine on busi ness. After I had sent a consign ment away I left for that place by horseback at 3 o’clock on Friday. Before going I sent a letter to the Secretary, advising him it would be necessary to postpone the meeting, also sent word to both Vice-Presi dqnts to that effect. I knew the Q.F.I.T. meeting was being held oh the Bth also. The letter to the Secretary was missorted into an other box, and not handed in until the following day, Saturday, at 12 o’clock. I have been told by a member that one -' Vice-President telephoned my request to the Secre tary to postpone the meeting. . The Secretary told him a meeting would be held, notwithstanding s my (the Chairman’s) notice. I have been twice elected Chairman, and it is my right and duty-to arrange dates of the month for these meetings. And I look to members to support the Chairman. Are we school children that we should be , run by any secretary who is paid for his services? The Vice-President has already verified the mistake re the Secretary’s letter at the Post Office. This unpleasantness between Chair man and Secretary has originated through the Chairman authorising the Secretary to call the following meeting, giving all the members a chance, instead of a few chosen ones. , ,f ■ Bowen Producers and National Political Association. - A Special Meeting ot the Bowen Producers aijd National Political Association will be held'iu the Shire Hall Board Room on Saturday next, 11th inst., at 8.30 p.m, . Business Choice of Candidate for the forthcoming plebiscite to be taken for the selection of a candi date, for the Bowen Seat at next State Elections.

POLITICAL.

Mr J. Mann, addressed a meeting of members of the Bowen Producers and al Political Association and

others in the School of Arts on Thursday, evening last on “The Poltical Situation, Pres ent and Puture.” Mr GL E. Kent (Chairman of the Assoc iation) occupied the chair and in a few words introduced the speaker who gave, a very inter esting: address and- was,, ap plauded throughout. It was not intended to admit other than members of the Associa tion but they gradually drifted ip until there was a fair num ber of non-members present, including many Labour , sup porters, some of. whom occas ionally fired a shot at the speaker, who handled inter-/ jectors cleverly. Owing to the . meeting not being adverised as public, and the usual courtesy not being extended to’ the Press we are unable to give full details of Mr Mann’s speech. After the speaker had concluded the Chairman rose to make an explanation of matters pondected with the taking of the plebiscite and commenced to read a letter from the Proserpine Branch on the matter but was howled down and for some time a < pandemonium reigned. Even tually Mr Kent, after an ap- • peal for fair play had been made, managed to say a few, words but was unable to pro perly explain mattersowing to the continued interruptions of prominent members and the meeting broke up in disorder. Mr Kent claims that Mr Mann’s nomination was not in order and threatens, if he is not given a fair hearing to come out as an independent candidate. The Labour sup porters present applauded Mr Kent and cheered him as he left the stage which brought forth. counter cheers for Mr , Mann. Labour supporters were delighted and if the farce continues the Bowen seat will be a fairly sure thing for Mr Collins. ,

CORRESPONDENCE

To .the Editor.

Yours faithfully, J. EYRE MASSY.

[We do not hold ourselves responsible for opinions expressed by correspondents.]

Sir.—Permit me to publish some facts in regard to Mr Kent and his imaginary grievance against mem bers of the Bowen Producers and

National Political Associatisn. Mr Kent, when Chairman of the Asso ciation, became a candidate in the recent local plebiscite, and was de feated by Mr John Mann. When the Chairman of a Local Authority becomes a candidate for a seat bn the Local Authority concered, he ceases to hold office as Chairman. When a Chairman of an Association such as the Bowen Producers and National Political Association be comes a candidate for a plebiscite, it is usual for the Chairman to cease to hold office as Chairman. Long useage is a law sufficient. By corn mom usage, then, Mr Kent should have ceased to hold office as Chair man, but he has not yet had the or dinary common decency to resign the position. From the time he ; became a candidate in the recent plebiscite, any business transacted by him as Chairman was illegal: Of how much value then, was the advertisement referred to as having ; been inserted by him, other than the amount of excitement and amusement afforded to the members of the. Association, at his expense and to the detriment of }he objects of an Association, of which he claims to be the father (a bad fath-; er surely). Mr Kent misconstrues the reading of Rule 8 to suit his own ends and disregards his Solici tor’s correct interpretation of the the same, which, in effect, is (hat ' the Secretary shall convene meetings, He had no justification for attempting to use Mr Mann’s meeting as a means to give vent to his own miserable feelings of jeal ousy. or a place at which to ad versely criticise Mr Mann’s candid ature for the forthcoming general plebiscite. He claimed the right to preside at the meeting and disgrace fully prostituted the position. The aftermath, in the street, in-so-far-as Mr Kent was concerned, was de plorable, so much that a limb of the la\y gave him paternal advice. He claims’ that Mt Mann’s nomination, is not in order, but has not yet thought fit to refer the matter to the Association’s .Executive for remedy. In a letter to the Chair man, Lower Burdekin ! Producers and National Political Association, he holds out the miserable threat that his. supporters (Labour) will nominate him as an Independent candidate for the Bowen seat at next State Elections. Such tactics as those of Mr Kent should afford ample ‘{food for thought” for corr espondents , such as “Broadmind ed” and "Fairpla^.”

J; T, M’Farlane claimed from Wil liam Wrangham the sun*.of £7/7/7 for money paid' in respect of a trip to Bowen on which Mrs Wraug ham accompanied Mr and Mrs M’Farlane. Evidence was given by complaintant in which it was stated that he agreed to pay Mrs )Vrangham’s expenses on the under standing that the defendant was to refund the money when in more prosperous circumstances.—The de fendant, giving evidence, stated that his wife went with the M’Farlanes as companion to Mrs, M’Farlane, and it was agreed that the com plainant would “shout they trip.” A witness was called by the defend ant. After hearing arguments from both solicitors his .Worship said on the evidence of the inde pendent witness he could only come to the,one the trip Was “shouted” by the complainant. —and; he, therefore gave judgment, in favour of the defendant Wrang ham.
